case: A 72-year-old man in pre-op for elective open inguinal hernia repair. Currently on clopidogrel after coronary stent 18 months ago. Should he stop it pre-op? [1/2023M_5/2023M_6/2023R]

explanation.correct: Clopidogrel irreversibly inhibits platelets for their lifespan (~7 days). Must be discontinued a week before surgery to avoid dangerous bleeding. After 12 months from stent placement, it’s usually safe to hold if low cardiac risk.

incorrect.reason: Bleeding risk is very high with open surgery.
One missed dose won’t restore platelet function.
Longer than needed and unnecessarily increases risk of stent thrombosis.

case: 72-year-old man, pre-op thyroidectomy, on warfarin for AF. Ask if he needs to stop warfarin. [12/2020T_12/2021T_11/2023T]

explanation.correct: Warfarin is stopped 5 days before surgery to allow INR normalization. If high thromboembolic risk, bridging with LMWH may be needed.

incorrect.reason: INR takes days, not hours, to normalize.
Way too long, exposes to AF thromboembolism risk.

case: 52-year-old diabetic man with irreducible tender inguinoscrotal swelling, distension, vomiting, fever. X-ray: air-fluid levels. Sugar 385. Next step? [multi years]

explanation.correct: Classic strangulated hernia (irreducible, obstructed, septic picture). Surgery immediately—do NOT delay for sugar control.

incorrect.option: Correct hyperglycemia then surgery next day
incorrect.reason: Delay risks bowel necrosis—a fatal error.
Very dangerous, risks reducing necrotic bowel back inside.

case: 9-month-old with irreducible left groin swelling, testes in scrotum. Best management? [multi years]

explanation.correct: Incarcerated hernia in infant (irreducible, firm). Must be reduced surgically (emergency herniotomy). No orchidopexy since testes are already normal.

incorrect.reason: No undescended testes, no orchidopexy needed.

case: 65-year-old male, uncontrolled DM, post perianal abscess drainage, now genital pain, crepitus, necrotic scrotal skin. Dx? [multi exams]

explanation.correct: Rapidly spreading necrotizing fasciitis of perineum/scrotum. Crepitus, dusky skin confirm Fournier’s gangrene.

incorrect.reason: Localized, testis tenderness, no necrosis gas.
Superficial strep infection, sharply demarcated—not necrotizing fasciitis.

case: 1y old boy, severe colicky pain, vomiting, PR exam: blood + mass. Dx? [multi exams]

explanation.correct: Triad: colicky pain + ‘red currant jelly stool’ (blood+ mucus) + palpable PR mass = Intussusception.

incorrect.reason: Nonbilious vomiting in neonate, no PR blood.
Bilious vomiting, shock, not rectal blood mass.
Causes painless PR bleeding—not colicky pain.
Bloody diarrhea possible, but colic + mass is not typical.

case: 70yo woman Parkinson’s, painless massive distension, tympanic, X-ray 'coffee bean'. Dx? [multi exams]

explanation.correct: Coffee-bean sign = pathognomonic sigmoid volvulus on X-ray. Rapid painless distension typical.

incorrect.reason: Local lump, not massive bowel gas.
Obstruction, but not coffee-bean shaped gas.
Ogilvie’s mimics obstruction but lacks 'coffee-bean' twisting.

case: 68yo woman, recurrent rapid distension, X-ray: coffee bean. Dx? [8/2024R]

explanation.correct: Recurrent obstructive episodes, coffee-bean → sigmoid volvulus.

incorrect.reason: Common post-surgery—she had no surgery hx.
Would not resolve conservatively and recur like volvulus.
Shows apple-core lesion on imaging, not coffee-bean.

case: 15yo boy with acute RLQ pain, but intra-op: normal appendix/cecum, terminal ileum edematous with fibrin. Best management? [2/2024R]
correctAnswer: Close the abdomen after culturing the exudate.

explanation.correct: Terminal ileitis (Yersinia, Crohn’s possible) → supportive, not immediate resection. Sample/culture fluid, close abdomen.

incorrect.reason: Too radical for acute inflammatory ileitis.
Reserved for Crohn’s complications, not initial.

case: 50yo man, 3-day vomiting, 20y ulcer pain hx, relief with milk, visible gastric waves, epigastric fullness. Dx? [2/2024R]

explanation.correct: Chronic duodenal ulcer → scarring/pyloric stenosis → GOO = visible waves, vomiting, relief by antacids.

incorrect.reason: Would not give succussion splash & visible gastric peristalsis.
No Murphy or RUQ tenderness in chronic ulcer history.

case: 45yo man with soft movable posterior neck mass, pseudo-fluctuation. Dx? [2/2024R]

explanation.correct: Soft, mobile, pseudo-fluctuant → lipoma hallmark. Sebaceous cyst would have central punctum, abscess would be tender, dermoid congenital midline.

case: 39yo male with Charcot’s triad (RUQ pain+fever+jaundice), gallstones, dilated CBD. On IV antibiotics, still febrile. Next step? [2/2024R]

explanation.correct: Acute ascending cholangitis not improving → urgent CBD decompression by ERCP (gold standard).

incorrect.reason: Good for gallbladder infections, not CBD stones.

case: 18yo man with 7 days painless rectal bleeding, external exam normal. Next step? [2/2024R]
correctAnswer: Referral to a gastroenterologist for colonoscopy

explanation.correct: Young patient with bleeding but normal exam must have whole colon visualized → colonoscopy.

incorrect.reason: Would miss proximal lesions like polyps or IBD.

case: 82yo man, SBO symptoms, X-ray parrot’s beak, no hernia/surgery hx. Best next step? [2/2024R]

explanation.correct: Classic volvulus (parrot beak). Old patient, obstructed, toxic abdomen → must undergo laparotomy, not conservative wait.

incorrect.reason: Temporizes, but volvulus needs definitive surgery.
Sometimes decompression can be attempted if stable, but mostly laparotomy is standard here.

case: 53yo man with LLQ pain, fever, sigmoid diverticulitis + 8cm abscess. Perc drainage & antibiotics done, now resolved, colonoscopy shows diverticula only. Next step? [2/2024R]
correctAnswer: Expectant management with sigmoid resection if symptoms recur

explanation.correct: After percutaneous drainage + recovery, only diverticula remain. Resection not mandatory unless recurrence/complications.

incorrect.reason: Not needed after single controlled episode.
Not standard; not safe long term.

case: A 70-year-old woman with cholelithiasis, now SBO symptoms. X-ray: spherical density RLQ. Dx & definitive treatment? [2/2024R]

explanation.correct: Gallstone ileus (gallstone passed into bowel via fistula, causing obstruction). Best treatment = enterotomy + extraction of obstructing gallstone. Later, elective cholecystectomy/fistula repair can be planned.

case: 22yo man, large facial laceration from ear to mouth corner. Most likely injured structure? [8/2024R]

explanation.correct: The parotid (Stensen’s) duct crosses cheek from near ear → pierces buccinator → oral cavity near molars. Laceration from ear to mouth corner risks parotid duct directly.

incorrect.reason: Drains floor of mouth, not cheek.
Nerve runs along jawline, not cheek cut trajectory.

case: 45yo woman RUQ pain radiates shoulder, afebrile. US: cystic duct stone. Next step? [8/2024R]

explanation.correct: Symptomatic biliary colic with documented stone → definitive treatment is cholecystectomy. NSAIDs relieve pain but won’t prevent recurrence.

incorrect.reason: May dissolve cholesterol stones, but too slow and partial.
For CBD stones, not cystic duct stone.

case: 60yo alcoholic man, hematemesis, cirrhosis stigmata. NG aspirate: blood. After resuscitation, next step? [8/2024R]

explanation.correct: Sclerotic patient, hematemesis likely variceal bleed. Initial resus, then urgent endoscopy to identify and treat varices (band ligate/sclerose).

incorrect.reason: Less useful here, more in arterial non-variceal bleeds.

case: 2yo boy with reducible right groin lump (after sedation). Planned repair 48h later. Best management? [multi exams]

explanation.correct: Children undergo simple herniotomy (sac ligation). No mesh repairs like Bassini/Shouldice, which are adult techniques.

case: 39yo man, groin swelling descends to scrotum, reducible, positive indirect ring test. Dx? [2/2023S]

explanation.correct: Indirect hernia follows inguinal canal, passes into scrotum, and ring occlusion test positive at deep ring.

incorrect.reason: Bulges directly, rarely into scrotum, ring occlusion negative.

case: 43yo woman, 3x4cm bluish non-tender mass medial to femoral pulse, disappears supine, associated long saphenous varices. Dx? [multi exams]

explanation.correct: Saphenous vein varix at SFJ = soft, bluish lump with cough impulse, disappears lying down, associated with varicosities.

incorrect.reason: Fatty, firm, not bluish, no impulse.
Firm lump, usually tender, no blue vein appearance.
Solid, no impulse or disappearance supine.

case: 61yo man, jaundice, itching, vague pain. CEA 523, CA19-9 450, CT: bulky pancreas + liver mets. Management? [multi exams]

explanation.correct: Unresectable pancreatic carcinoma (liver mets). Palliative stent relieves jaundice/itching. Curative Whipple impossible here.

case: 50yo woman, SBO + pain radiating to inner thigh/knee, no prior surgery. Dx? [11/2022R]

explanation.correct: Howship-Romberg sign = inner thigh/knee pain due to obturator nerve compression with obturator hernia. SBO with no previous surgery fits.

incorrect.reason: Causes obstruction but not radiating thigh pain.
Groin lump palpable, not hidden obturator hernia.

case: During open hernia repair surgeon asks which does *not* form inguinal canal boundary. [multi exams]

explanation.correct: Inguinal canal boundaries: Roof (IO + TA), Floor (inguinal ligament), Ant (EO aponeurosis), Post (TF + conjoint tendon). Pectineal ligament is part of femoral canal boundary, not inguinal canal.

case: During a repair of inguinal hernia, which nerve is within the spermatic cord? [8/2024S]
correctAnswer: Genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve

explanation.correct: The genital branch runs inside spermatic cord with artery to cremaster, supplying cremasteric muscle and scrotum.

incorrect.reason: Close to cord, runs in canal, but outside chord proper.
Only the genital branch enters cord, femoral branch doesn't.
Supplies abdominal wall, not in cord.
Runs near ASIS, no relation to cord.

case: 82yo woman, painful groin swelling, firm, tender, irreducible. Most likely Dx? [multi exams]

explanation.correct: Elderly female, tender irreducible groin lump below ligament → classical femoral hernia (commonly incarcerated/strangulated).

case: 70yo smoker, right inguinal lump, reduces on lying, doesn’t go to scrotum, urinary sx. Dx? [multi exams]

explanation.correct: Older male, lump above ligament, doesn’t reach scrotum = direct inguinal hernia (from posterior wall weakness).

incorrect.reason: In cord, not reducible via cough impulse.
Would extend into scrotum, tender irreducible.

case: 20yo male with testicular swelling, ↑LDH, mildly ↑hCG, AFP normal. Dx? [multi exams]

explanation.correct: Seminoma: ↑LDH, may have mild hCG rise, normal AFP. Teratoma raises AFP typically.

case: 30yo man, dragging hemi-scrotal swelling ‘bag of worms’, disappears supine. Dx? [multi exams]

explanation.correct: Classic → ‘bag of worms’, reducible when lying down, caused by dilated pampiniform plexus.

case: 27yo man, 2-day testicular pain + fever, swelling, scrotal redness. Dx? [multi exams]

explanation.correct: Gradual onset, fever, tender epididymis/testis, scrotal erythema → infection = epididymo-orchitis. Torsion is acute severe onset.

incorrect.reason: Sudden severe pain, not gradual with fever.
Acute child pain, blue spot sign.
Groin lump with obstruction signs, not infection-like picture.

case: 56yo post-appendicectomy, sudden SOB after cyclizine. HR 122, BP 86/48, sats 85%. What give first? [multi exams]

explanation.correct: Classic anaphylaxis after drug (cyclizine). Priority = IM adrenaline first. Others supportive afterward.

incorrect.reason: Adjunct for bronchospasm, not first priority.

case: 24yo with colonoscopy showing multiple adenomatous polyps. Genetic syndrome? [multi exams]

explanation.correct: FAP variant with many adenoma polyps, assoc with osteomas, dental lesions, soft tissue tumours. Classic scenario.

incorrect.reason: Few colorectal + endometrial Ca. Not polyposis.

case: 62yo man, reducible groin lump, above ligament, no scrotal extension. Dx? [multi exams]

explanation.correct: Reducible swelling above ligament, not extending scrotum = direct inguinal hernia.

incorrect.reason: Occult, thigh pain not groin lump.

case: 56yo man, ultrasound = splenic abscess. Management? [11/2023R]

explanation.correct: Optimal treatment for splenic abscess = splenectomy, as it often harbours multiloculated resistant pus.

case: 44yo man scrotal swelling painless, transilluminates, testis not palpable. Dx? [multi exams]

explanation.correct: Cystic scrotal swelling encasing testis, transilluminates. That’s hydrocele, fluid in tunica vaginalis.

incorrect.reason: Tends to reduce, cough impulse present.
Bag of worms feel, not transillumination.

case: 67yo woman, groin lumps multiple nodes (2x2 and several axillary). Dx? [multi exams]

explanation.correct: Multiple firm lumps in groin + axilla = generalized lymphadenopathy, not hernia/varix.

case: 69yo smoker, limb pain, claudication 2 yrs, now acute worsening with pale cyanotic cold foot, absent femoral pulse. Dx? [multi exams]

explanation.correct: Sudden worsening on background of PAD = acute thrombosis/embolus: 6 Ps (pain, pallor, pulseless, poikilothermia, paresthesia, paralysis).

incorrect.reason: Causes swollen tender limb, pulses preserved.
Claudication, but here sudden acute change.
Young smokers, distal disease, not elderly with acute change.

case: 77yo male, rectal bleed, Dukes A adenoca. Tx? [2/2024R]

explanation.correct: Stage I (Dukes A) superficial limited lesion = local excision is curative, no need for radical resection.

incorrect.reason: For low rectal advanced lesions + sphincter removal.
Palliative, not needed for early stage.
For advanced tumors, not Dukes A.

case: 62yo woman with eczematoid areolar lesion ×3 months, nipple inverted, firm area. Which next step? [2/2024R]

explanation.correct: Suspicious lesion = Paget’s disease of breast (underlying carcinoma). Must do imaging + tissue biopsy. Creams and lotions only delay dx.

incorrect.reason: Galactogram for nipple discharge, not here.

case: 62yo post laparoscopic hernia repair, can’t urinate ×6h, suprapubic fullness. Next step? [2/2024R]

explanation.correct: Post-op acute urinary retention is common. Simple bladder catheterization decompresses. SPC only if urethral route impossible.

incorrect.reason: Second line if urethral catheter fails.

case: 18yo man, MVC, coma GCS7, BP 60/0 after fluids only rises to 70/30, abdomen distended. Next step? [2/2024R]

explanation.correct: Severe hypotension, abdominal distension not improving with fluids = intra-abdominal bleed → urgent laparotomy. Imaging wastes time.

case: 42yo woman, intermittent painless soft thigh mass, disappears with compression. Dx? [2/2024R]

explanation.correct: Venous swelling at saphenofemoral junction → soft, compressible, disappears lying supine, associated with varicosities.

incorrect.reason: Would extend to scrotum, not just thigh crease.

case: 64yo man, peri-umbilical mass, expansile pulsation. Screening test? [multi exams]

explanation.correct: First-line AAA screening = abdominal ultrasonography (simple, safe, sensitive).

incorrect.reason: May show calcification but not reliable.
Invasive, used for surgery planning only.

case: 23yo male ascites, SAAG <1.1, adhesions. Best diagnostic tool? [multi exams]

explanation.correct: Low SAAG (<1.1) = exudative (TB, carcinomatosis, peritoneal disease). Direct visualization via laparoscopy + biopsy is gold.

incorrect.reason: May detect malignancy but low yield.

case: 40yo male post-appendectomy, SBO suspicion. Which exam finding is most likely? [multi exams]

explanation.correct: SBO → tinkling, high-pitched metallic bowel sounds + distension. This is most distinct bedside finding.

case: Most definitive method to diagnose necrotizing soft tissue infection (NSTI)? [multi exams]

explanation.correct: NSTI diagnosis is ultimately surgical—when in doubt, cut it out. Imaging/labs support but aren’t definitive.

incorrect.reason: Can show fascial gas but not gold standard.

case: 22yo male with LUQ mass. How to differentiate kidney vs spleen? [multi exams]

explanation.correct: Kidney is retroperitoneal, ballotable between hands. Spleen is intraperitoneal, not ballotable. Splenic notch differentiates spleen.

incorrect.reason: Spleen enlarges toward RLQ, kidney doesn’t.

case: 35yo woman painful breast lump post nursing, fever, erythema, tender. Dx & management? [multi exams]

explanation.correct: Breast abscess in lactating woman. Drain + antibiotics is curative. Imaging not needed prior.

incorrect.reason: Not first line in acute infection with abscess formed.
Sometimes an option, but classic management is I&D.
Chronic periductal mastitis, not acute abscess.

case: Intra-op colon ca with solitary liver met, otherwise normal. Best management? [2/2024R]
correctAnswer: Performing right hemicolectomy and wide excision of the liver lesion

explanation.correct: Synchronous resectable isolated liver metastasis: remove primary + metastasis. Potentially curative.

incorrect.reason: Unnecessarily extensive if wedge excision suffices.

case: 25yo football trauma, LUQ pain, shoulder tip pain, hypotension. Hx malaria. Dx? [multi exams]

explanation.correct: Acute LUQ pain radiating to shoulder (Kehr’s sign), shock, rigid peritoneum = ruptured spleen. Malaria hx predisposes to splenomegaly rupture.

incorrect.reason: Pain but not acute hemorrhage shock.

case: 24yo man with excised melanoma, biopsy. Which factor most predictive outcome? [2/2024R]

explanation.correct: Breslow depth (vertical thickness) is most prognostic factor. Deeper = worse outcome.

incorrect.reason: Bad sign but secondary prognostic value.

case: Best management for newly agitated ward patient? [multi exams]

explanation.correct: Haloperidol is standard for acute agitation in hospital ward setting. Benzos may worsen confusion. Antiepileptics irrelevant.

incorrect.reason: Used in ICU sedation, not ward agitation.
Chronic seizure/mood stabilizers, not acute management.

case: Which is 'time out' in OR? [multi exams]
options: Inside OR ensure patient ID, side, planned operation
correctAnswer: It is done inside the operating room for ensuring patient identity, type and side of the operation

explanation.correct: WHO surgical checklist ‘time-out’ = pause before incision to confirm patient, site, procedure. Prevents wrong-site surgery.

incorrect.reason: Done night before in old practice, not this.

case: 75yo woman, right iliac fossa mass, recurrent PR bleed. Colonoscopy: caecal adenoca. Best surgery? [multi exams]

explanation.correct: Standard operation for caecal carcinoma = right hemicolectomy. Extended resections for transverse colon etc.

incorrect.reason: For hepatic flexure/transverse ca, not caecum strictly.

case: 75yo female, RIF mass, recurrent rectal bleeding. Colonoscopy: caecal mass, biopsy adenocarcinoma grade II. Surgical treatment? [multi exams]

explanation.correct: For caecal carcinoma extending toward hepatic flexure, the standard oncologic operation is extended right hemicolectomy with ileocolic and middle colic vessel ligation.

incorrect.reason: Standard for ceacal but here mass size often demands extended resection.
Reserved for diffuse polyposis/FAP, not localized tumor.

case: 80yo man, cholelithiasis, SBO signs. Which finding most confirms gallstone ileus? [2/2024R]

explanation.correct: Air in biliary tree (pneumobilia) + obstruction = pathognomonic for gallstone ileus due to cholecystoenteric fistula.

case: 60yo man with anal itching worsens day end, salesman standing all day. No fever or bleeding. Likely diagnosis? [2/2024R]

explanation.correct: External hemorrhoids cause perianal discomfort/itching aggravated by prolonged standing, no bleeding necessarily.

incorrect.reason: Severe pain with defecation and bleeding.

case: 70yo ex-smoker, weight loss + dysphagia progressing to solids & liquids, nausea/vomiting. What causes vomiting? [multi exams]

explanation.correct: Dysphagia progressive from solids → liquids, obstructs, causing food stasis → regurgitation/vomiting.

incorrect.reason: Vomiting possible but dysphagia hallmark of esophageal cancer.

case: 65yo woman with 8 days abdominal distension, colicky pain, 12h vomiting. First investigation? [multi exams]
correctAnswer: CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis

explanation.correct: Suspected large bowel obstruction—CT is gold initial investigation to confirm site/cause/complication.

incorrect.reason: Diagnostic but unsafe in acute obstruction.

case: 23yo man acute anal pain post defecation, persists hours, bright red blood, unable for exam due to spasm. Dx? [multi exams]

explanation.correct: Severe pain with defecation, bright blood on paper, sphincter spasm = anal fissure classic.

incorrect.reason: Painless bright red bleeding, not severe pain.
Discharge but not severe pain with defecation.

case: 28yo male, painless testis enlargement, firm, nodular. Next best diagnostic step? [2/2024R]

explanation.correct: First-line imaging for testis swellings = scrotal US. Then tumor markers, then definitive orchiectomy (not biopsy—risk seeding).

incorrect.reason: Do once confirmed, not before US.

case: 64yo post hemicolectomy, calf DVT on duplex. Initial management? [2/2024R]

explanation.correct: Start anticoagulation with LMWH/heparin immediately for acute DVT. Then transition to warfarin/DOACs. Stockings are adjuncts.

case: 12yo girl gunshot knee shrapnel + local swelling, non-pulsatile hematoma, small fracture. Next step? [multi exams]

explanation.correct: Expanding hematoma suggests vascular injury. Non-pulsatile = not active bleed yet. CT angio confirms site before surgery.

incorrect.reason: Do after imaging unless uncontrolled hemorrhage.
Must check vessels before ortho fixation.
Less accurate, CT angio gold in trauma.

case: 75yo man with LIF pain, fever, WBC ↑, CRP ↑. Diagnosis? [multi exams]

explanation.correct: Elderly, LIF tenderness, fever, labs ↑ = diverticulitis till proven otherwise.

incorrect.reason: Causes severe pain out of proportion and peritonitis.

case: 24yo male, pain + fresh blood PR, sentinel skin tag, intolerant of exam (spasm). Dx? [multi exams]

explanation.correct: Sentinel pile (skin tag), severe pain, spasm, fresh blood = fissure classic.

incorrect.reason: Bleeding but painless or mild pain.
Episodic intense rectal pain, no visible lesion.
Presents as chronic bleeding, not fissure features.

case: 48yo woman suspicious mammogram lesion → stereotactic biopsy = LCIS. Appropriate counseling? [2/2024R]
options: Tamoxifen prevents spread; increases contralateral risk
correctAnswer: You can consider non-operative treatment with close observation, annual mammograms, and semiannual clinical examinations

explanation.correct: LCIS is a risk marker, not obligate precursor. Observation + surveillance (sometimes chemoprevention) is standard.

incorrect.reason: Reserved for strong family/genetic risk, not LCIS routine.

case: 22yo male acute appendicitis pain localized RIF, rebound tenderness. Feature of non-complicated appendicitis? [multi exams]
correctAnswer: Crossed tenderness on pressing left iliac fossa

explanation.correct: Rovsing’s sign (pain in RLQ when pressing LLQ) is a feature of uncomplicated appendicitis.

case: Post-appendectomy histology = 1 cm tip carcinoid. Asymptomatic. Next intervention? [2/2024R]

explanation.correct: Appendiceal carcinoid <2 cm at tip → cured by appendectomy. Hemicolectomy needed if >2 cm, meso-base or lymphatic spread.

incorrect.reason: Not necessary for 1 cm tip lesion.

case: 41yo woman thought appendicitis, intra-op: normal appendix, terminal ileitis with creeping mesenteric fat, 30 cm length. Next action? [2/2024R]

explanation.correct: Findings suggest Crohn’s ileitis. Do not resect in acute setting unless complication (obstruction/perforation). Close abdomen; disease is medical.

case: 74yo woman, painful foot ulcer. Punched out, pale deep base, thin dry skin. Likely etiology? [multi exams]

explanation.correct: Arterial ulcers are painful, punched-out, pale, with surrounding shiny tight skin. Distal ischemia hallmark.

incorrect.reason: Shallow, at medial malleolus, with edema.
May be neuropathic or infected, but skin here described ischemic.

case: 53yo man, big toe ulcer, calf claudication eased by rest, cool peripheries, poor pulses. Dx? [multi exams]

explanation.correct: Classic ischemic ulcer due to PAD, deep painful ulcer of toes/foot, with claudication and absent pulses.

case: 55yo woman, heaviness & cramping leg, relief by elevation. Ulcer above medial malleolus, non-pitting edema, superficial varicosities. Dx? [8/2024R]

explanation.correct: Typical venous ulcer related to perforator incompetence: medial aspect, relieved by elevation, edema, varicosities.

incorrect.reason: Can cause, but medial perforators classically blamed.

case: 70yo post partial gastrectomy 30y ago, now pain, vomiting, wt loss. Most likely Dx? [8/2024R]

explanation.correct: Post-gastrectomy gastric stump carcinoma risk decades later. Alarm symptoms: weight loss, obstruction-like vomiting = malignancy.

incorrect.reason: Possible, but weight loss/mass favors cancer.
Causes postprandial hypoglycemia or diarrhea, not wt loss & obstruction.

case: 70yo woman, jaundice, small head of pancreas mass 2 cm, no vascular invasion. Next step? [8/2024R]

explanation.correct: Resectable pancreatic head mass (small, no invasion) → pancreaticoduodenectomy (Whipple).

incorrect.reason: Already staged by CT—resectable so proceed definitive.

case: 58yo woman urge incontinence worsening ×2y, hx perineal tear delivery. Investigation? [8/2024R]

explanation.correct: To evaluate sphincter tone/rectal pressures, required in urge incontinence due to possible sphincter weakness post tear.

incorrect.reason: Colorectal cancer exclusion, not incontinence evaluation.

case: 59yo female with hematemesis, hypotension. NGT aspirate fresh blood. After resus, next? [multi exams]

explanation.correct: Upper GI bleed must have urgent endoscopy to diagnose and treat cause once stabilized. Ultrasound/hospitalize comes later.

incorrect.reason: Not first-line, reserved for refractory cases.

case: 65yo woman, large breast mass ≥6 cm fixed to wall + axillary nodes. After mammography, next step? [multi exams]

explanation.correct: Suspicious breast mass diagnosis: core needle biopsy preferred (provides architecture, hormone receptor testing). FNAC insufficient alone.

incorrect.reason: Not for large fixed mass, may compromise surgery.

case: 31yo lactating female, painful breast ×2d, fever, chills. Erythema tender swelling. Dx? [multi exams]

explanation.correct: Classic lactational abscess: fever, tender erythematous lump requiring I&D.

incorrect.reason: Looks similar but chronic, no acute fever.

case: 48yo man heavy NSAID use, severe epigastric pain, rigid board abdomen. Diagnosis? [multi exams]

explanation.correct: NSAID-induced peptic ulcer → sudden severe epigastric pain with guarding/rigid abdomen = perforated ulcer.

incorrect.reason: RUQ pain, not epigastric rigid abdomen.

case: 24yo woman, neck swelling in carotid triangle, aspiration = cholesterol crystals. Dx? [8/2024R]

explanation.correct: Classic branchial cyst: lateral neck, cholesterol crystals in aspirate.

case: Which is NOT convenient for mastalgia treatment? [multi exams]

explanation.correct: Mastalgia is managed conservatively (evening primrose oil, danazol, bromocriptine). Surgery inappropriate.

case: 64yo man weight loss, mild back pain → 2wks later jaundice, pale stools, palpable RUQ mass. Dx? [multi exams]

explanation.correct: Symptoms: obstructive painless jaundice, palpable gallbladder = Courvoisier’s sign, likely pancreatic carcinoma head.

case: 62yo TPN, high fever 8h, catheter site erythema. Mgmt? [2/2024R]
options: Remove catheter + culture, replace via guidewire
Remove catheter + culture, new line at another site
Remove catheter + culture, establish peripheral IV
correctAnswer: Removing catheter, sending for culture and establish peripheral intravenous line

explanation.correct: Suspected central line sepsis: remove suspected line, send tip for culture, and establish alternative peripheral access until blood cultures guide new line.

incorrect.reason: Better to use peripheral until stabilize/cultures known.

case: 75yo woman with transverse colon nearly obstructing carcinoma, biopsy adenoca grade III. Surgical option? [multi exams]

explanation.correct: For transverse colon carcinoma → extended right hemicolectomy ensures adequate lymphovascular clearance.

case: 43yo man severe chest pain after repeated vomiting. Esophagram: rupture proximal to GEJ. Preferred operative exposure? [2/2024R]

explanation.correct: Boerhaave syndrome (spontaneous esophageal rupture) near distal esophagus/GEJ → best exposed via left thoracotomy.

incorrect.reason: Better for mid-esophagus, not distal GEJ.
Overly extensive unless extension is proven.
Doesn’t give good access to distal thoracic esophagus.

case: 45yo woman, NSAID-induced duodenal ulcer perforation, 30hr duration. Best operation? [2/2024R]

explanation.correct: Emergency perforated peptic ulcer = Graham’s patch (omental plug). Definitive anti-ulcer surgery is avoided in unstable/late presentation.

incorrect.reason: Elective anti-secretory surgeries, not for acutely ill patient.

case: Polyp excision 2×1.5 cm villous adenoma, carcinoma in situ, 1 cm above anal verge. Next step? [2/2024R]
correctAnswer: Reexcision of the biopsy site with wider margins

explanation.correct: Villous adenoma with carcinoma in situ requires local wide excision to ensure complete removal. APR only for invasive low tumor.

case: 27yo man painless firm nodular swollen testis. Dx? [multi exams]

explanation.correct: Hard, irregular, painless unilateral testicular mass in young man → considered testicular cancer until proven otherwise.

case: 35yo woman chronic constipation, severe anal pain + bleeding, tender fissure + skin tag. Definitive surgery? [multi exams]

explanation.correct: Gold standard for chronic fissure unresponsive to medical = lateral internal sphincterotomy. Relieves spasm, heals fissure.

case: 25yo woman simple ovarian cyst 4 cm, asymptomatic. Next best step? [multi exams]

explanation.correct: Simple <5 cm ovarian cyst in young asymptomatic women → observation, most resolve spontaneously.

case: 64yo man 5 days post rectal resection, fever, tender rigid abdomen, hypotension. Dx? [multi exams]

explanation.correct: Post resection day 5–7 peritonitis + shock strongly suggests anastomotic leak.

case: 25yo male post severe pancreatitis, enlarging pseudocyst ×2wks, symptomatic. Next step? [multi exams]
correctAnswer: Laparotomy and internal drainage of the cyst

explanation.correct: Symptomatic, enlarging pseudocyst after 6 wks maturity → internal drainage (cystogastrostomy /cystojejunostomy).

case: 55yo female advanced gastric Ca with outlet obstruction. Which statement is true? [multi exams]
options: GJ has more complications than stent
correctAnswer: Compared to gastrojejunostomy, endoscopic stenting is associated with better short-term outcomes as well as shorter hospital length of stay

explanation.correct: Endoscopic duodenal stenting palliation relieves obstruction faster, less invasive. GJ long-term more durable.

incorrect.reason: Both options available, stenting widely used.

case: 45yo man, epigastric pain, fullness, diarrhea, wt loss. CT: pancreatic head calcification + 7 cm tail cyst. Dx? [multi exams]

explanation.correct: Large cystic lesion + calcified head indicates synchronous chronic changes but cystic neoplasm (mucinous cystadenoma) most likely for large tail lesion.

incorrect.reason: Chronic fits calcification, but 7 cm cystic lesion likely neoplasm.

case: 45yo woman 2y post breast Ca surgery + chemo, now RUQ pain. CT: 2 masses in right liver lobe. Dx? [multi exams]

explanation.correct: Breast Ca → common metastasis to liver. Multiple right lobe lesions = metastases.

incorrect.reason: Occurs with cirrhosis, not post breast Ca.

case: 28yo male, recurrent tender anorectal swelling, fever, external fistula opening, fluctuant collection. Best management? [multi exams]

explanation.correct: Recurrent fistula with abscess needs EUA → allows drainage + exploration of fistula tract. Ward drainage/antibiotics alone not sufficient.

incorrect.reason: Useful in complex cases but surgery is gold.
